channel.title: Assist me in building a setup?
channel.description:
Hello [s]ladies and[/s] gentlemen, as you can tell from the title I need help with building a new PC. First of all, I know spoon feeding is bad, but to be honest I really don't want to do a DIY and find out I've botched it somewhere along the line. I know nothing about hardware other than what RAM and CPU are for, thats about it... and I know a lot of you guys are guru's at this stuff.
My budget is around $800, but I'm not even sure that will fit for a fairly decent PC (I want to be able to game on it etc, but my main focus will be rendering video's which I can already tell takes 99x RAM and abit o' CPU)
So ya, halp?
Thanks guys! (Also, I'll edit this thread if I need to answer certain things to make my question more specific, I imagine it would look kindof too general atm).
I live in the UK, so preferably a UK/European (online) store.

item.title: Assist me in building a setup?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Ollie:

for casual gaming it would be fine, its when you want to game seriously then you need to start shedding out for higher priced components.

That’s the good thing about good integrated cards, you can afford higher priced other components (like more RAM, or a better CPU) and game until you have enough money to buy a really good video card as well.

Read full topic
item.source: Assist me in building a setup?

item.source: Assist me in building a setup?

item.title: Assist me in building a setup?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:35, topic:373409”][quote author=The_Flames link=topic=469421.msg3437017#msg3437017 date=1292819704]

You guys make so much sense!

Are you saying the aforementioned graphics card cannot allow HDMI output?!!1

Edit: Nvm, looked at motherboardt and saw 1 x HDMI Connector

Does “Max. Memory Share Up to 512 MB Support” mean it won’t be able to fully utilise 768mb on the graphics card? Or does shared memory just mean the integrated graphics thats already on there?

I think I may be learning stuff here, win!

Also, apologies if the thread is going on too long LoL

That means that the motherboard has an onboard graphics card, and you don’t need a separate one. ‘max 512mb shared memory’ means that the onboard card can use up to 512mb of your system memory, so if you have 3gb of RAM, your computer could use 2.5gb of ram, and the video card could use 512mb. Of course if you have another graphics card you can disable the onboard one and use all your RAM again.

Oh, makes sense. I always wondered what memory was for on a gfx card

[/quote]May be worth noting that while an integrated card can be very useful for debugging purposes, it’s pretty much useless for any kind of gaming use.[/quote]

Depends on what kind of card it is, there are integrated cards that are in the decent to good range. None of them are going to be top of the line cards, but some could be good enough for a gamer.

Read full topic

item.title: Assist me in building a setup?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

The_Flames:

Edit: One more thing (lool), don’t I need an optical drive to install an OS?

You can install it from a USB Drive.

http://www.ubuntu.com/desktop/get-ubuntu/download

Look at option 2.

or Windows 7

Into Windows – 11 Jan 12

Install Windows 7 From USB

Step by step procedure with screenshots to install Windows 7 and Windows 8 from USB drive or pen drive.

Read full topic

item.title: Assist me in building a setup?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“The_Flames, post:25, topic:373409”]K will purchase all that shit soon, inb4 badly placed lego.

Also, on a scale of 1-10 how good is that graphics card? (yes, a scale of 1-10, I know…)

EDIT: Also (LOL @ infinite questions), would it be possible to use my tv as the monitor, as a way to save money too by using HDMI or something, like would there be someone to use the hdmi cable with?[/quote]

If it’s an HD TV, then sure, it will make a fine monitor hooked up with an HDMI or a DVI cable. If you can’t hook it up that way, you might as well forget about it.

Read full topic

item.title: Assist me in building a setup?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Thug-life, post:22, topic:373409”]It is just like playing with expensive lego.[/quote]that

You can lower the cost a bit more without losing quality by the way. Get a Cooler Master Centurion 534 case. It is the one i use, and i’m very satisfied with it. It would work well for you as well, since it aims at minimizing the amount of screws you need, and instead has nifty clip-solutions everywhere.

Read full topic

item.description:

It is just like playing with expensive lego.

Except even idiots can build shit with Lego!

The_Flames:

One more question, then I’m all set; I can upgrade easily, right? I heard its fairly easy, although the people saying this may just be tech guru’s. Which then brings me back to the question, is it easy to build a PC D:

This video makes it look too easy. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QQQ30QoF_-8

item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

ok well, search overclockers.co.uk for a slightly worse processor (For example, a quad core instead of 6 core), you don’t really need 8GB of ram, so you can take off one of another £75.99 knocked off, you don’t need the ssd.

That’s a saving of what, £215 savings? that takes you to like £555.
